methods.body:
### First item

```javascript
var value = F.sitemap('sitemap-identificator', true);
value.sitemap     // current sitemap id
value.id          // current item id
value.name        // current item name
value.url         // current item url
value.wildcard    // does the current item url contain a wildcard routing?
```

### All items in tree

```javascript

var arr = F.sitemap('sitemap-identificator');

for (var i = 0, length = arr.length; i < length; i++) {
    value.sitemap   // current sitemap id
    value.id        // current item id
    value.name      // current item name
    value.url       // current item url
    value.last      // is the last item?
    value.first     // is the first item?
    value.index     // current item index in sitemap (in the parent tree)
    value.wildcard  // does the current item url contain a wildcard routing?
}```

api.body:
`FrameworkConfiguration` contains framework settings. Settings can be stored in these files:

```html
/app/config
/app/config-debug
/app/config-release
/app/config-rest
```

The `config` file is loaded for all framework modes (`release`, `debug`, `test`) and other configs are loaded according to the framework mode. The configuration file is a plain text file.

__Example__:

```html
name                         : My Web Site name
version                      : 1.01
author                       : Peter Sirka
secret                       : mySECRET1.01
default-image-quality        : 96
...
...
...
```

## Auto-Converting values with sub-type

The framework converts/binds values according the sub-type. So you can read converted values in the application:

```html
my-custom-object-raw      (Object)    : { name: 'Total.js', date: new Date() }
my-custom-object-json     (JSON)      : { "name": "Total.js" }
my-custom-number          (number)    : 320.34
my-custom-boolean         (boolean)   : true
my-custom-date            (date)      : 2016-07-26
my-custom-array           (array)     : [1, 2, 3, 4]
binds-environment-value   (env)       : process.env

// +v2.9.0 supports config linking
binds-config-value        (config)    : name
```

- [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools)

## Custom options for dependencies

`+v2.4.0` supports custom options for all dependencies.

```html
// type#name       (Object)  : { name: 'value', number: 30, boolean: false }
// a real example:
module#monitor     (Object)  : { url: '/mymonitor/'}```

properties.body: `F.cache` database will be stored on HDD each 1 minute. Cache is loaded from HDD automatically when the framework is started.

properties.body:
Enables a small console debugging. The framework creates snapshot of `F.usage()` automatically into the `/usage.log` file.

__Or alternative__:
```javascript
require('total.js').http('release', { debug: true });```
properties.name: allow-debug

properties.body:
Which files are allowed by the framework for handling static files? Values in config files have to be separated with the comma `,` (on one line).

__Default__:

```javascript
['.jpg', '.png', '.gif', '.ico', '.js', '.coffee', '.css', '.txt', '.xml', '.woff', '.woff2', '.otf', '.ttf', '.eot', '.svg', '.zip', '.rar', '.pdf', '.docx', '.xlsx', '.doc', '.xls', '.html', '.htm', '.appcache', '.map', '.ogg', '.mp4', '.mp3', '.webp', '.webm', '.swf', '.package', '.json', '.md']
```

__The config file declaration__:

```html
static-accepts            : .jpg, .ico, .js```
properties.name: static-accepts

properties.body:
This option adds all own values into `static-accepts` and it's not visible in `framework.config`. Values in config files have to be separated with comma `,` (on one line).

__The config file declaration__:

```html
static-accepts-custom        : .eps, .nosql```
properties.name: static-accepts-custom

properties.body:
Mail settings for `framework.mail()` or `controller.mail()`: this option sets SMTP options:

- `secure` (optional, default: `false`)
- `user` (optional, default: empty)
- `password` (optional, default: empty)
- `timeout` (optional, default: `10000`)
- `xoauth2` (optional) can contain a token in base64 encoding `+v2.8.0`

__Example:__
```json
{"secure":false,"port":25,"user":"","password":"","timeout":10000}```

api.name: DatabaseIndexes
api.body:
`+v3.0.0` __NoSQL Database Indexes__ is a simple engine for creating indexes for NoSQL embedded database. This engine creates several files for each index, it depends on documents.

### How does the engine create/store indexes?

If you create a new index then NoSQL embedded performs `reindexing` for the entire DB (only onetime). Then NoSQL creates/updates index when a document is inserted, modified or removed from/in main DB.

Index is meant as independent NoSQL embedded database which contains only these documents which are valid for the index settings. In other words: NoSQL can create many small DB files with indexed documents. Documents are cloned from main DB. NoSQL performs/uses same DB operations for indexes as in main database. In short: Indexes store documents into the seperated NoSQL embedded databases.

### How does the engine search in indexes?

It's very simple. Engine transforms searched value according to the type of index because it needs to get a name of database index file and in this file it will try to find a document/documents. Indexes support only two readonly operations: `.get()` (finds a specific document) and `.find()` (finds more documents).

### When is the right time for creating indexes?

If your DB will contain e.g. more documents (more than `50000`) or you will fell a slowdown. Indexes are fit for finding specific documents e.g. you want to find some order/product according to its number. Indexes don't have any effect when DB updates/removes documents, they are optimized for reading only.

### Where can I define indexes?

The best place for defining indexes are `definitions`. So just create a definition e.g. `indexes.js` and define all your indexes.

```javascript
var db = NOSQL('products');

// A simple index for ID
db.indexes.create('id');

// A multiple index
db.indexes.create('city', ['name', 'country']);
```

methods.body:
Reads and Writes cookies. __When the value is undefined then the method performs reading.__

__How to read cookie?__

```javascript
var value = controller.cookie('cookiename');
```

__How to write cookie?__

```javascript
controller.cookie('cookiename', 'VALUE', '5 days');
```

__How to remove cookie?__

```javascript
controller.cookie('cookiename', '', '-1 day');```
methods.name: controller.cookie

methods.body:
Returns a URL from `sitemap` file. The method performs `String.format()` for the selected URL address with additional arguments `1..n`.

__Sitemap__:

```html
homepage     : Homepage       --> /
products     : Products       --> /products/        --> homepage
category     : Category       --> /products/{0}/    --> products
```

```html
@{sitemap_url('category', 'shoes')}
<!-- OUTPUT: /products/shoes/ -->

@{sitemap_url('category', '')}
<!-- OUTPUT: /products// -->

@{sitemap_url('category', 'first', 'second')}
<!-- OUTPUT: /products/first/ -->```
methods.name: @{sitemap_url}

methods.body:

```html

E.g.:
sitemap url: /products/{0}/
-->
@{sitemap_replace('detail', model.title, model.linker)}

<!--
With functions:
-->
@{sitemap_replace('detail', current => current.format(model.title), current => current.replace('#', model.linker))}```

products     : Products       --> /products/        --> homepage

```

@{sitemap_name('category', 'Shoes')};

methods.body:
Download content or file from a url address.

__IMPORTANT__:
For DNS HOST CACHE use `dnscache` flag (auto-clear DNS cache: `config['default-interval-clear-dnscache']`).

__FLAGS__:
- `number` is considered as `timeout`
- `json` automatically serializes data to `json`
- `xhr` is supported too
- `dnscache` resolves IP from DNS
- supported encodings: `utf8` (default), `ascii`, `base64`, `binary` and `hex`
- supported content types: `html`, `plain`, `json` and `xml`
- supported methods: `get` (default), `post`, `put`, `delete`, `path`, `head` and `options`

methods.body:
Creates the request (GET/POST/DELETE/PUT) to the URL address with the custom params, cookies and headers. The method automatically serializes values (without xml and files).

__IMPORTANT__:
For DNS HOST CACHE use `dnscache` flag (auto-clear DNS cache: `config['default-interval-clear-dnscache']`).

__FLAGS__:
- `number` is considered as `timeout`
- `< 8` reads the content with maximum size `8 kB`
- `json` automatically serializes data to `json`
- `xhr` is supported too
- `dnscache` resolves IP from DNS
- `noredirect` disables auto-redirect (+v2.5.0)
- `raw` sends data as they are (+v2.5.0)
- supported encodings: `utf8` (default), `ascii`, `base64`, `binary` and `hex`
- supported content types: `html`, `plain`, `json` and `xml`
- supported methods: `get` (default), `post`, `put`, `delete`, `path`, `head` and `options`
- `+v2.9.2` adds a new flag called `cookies` for persistency of cookies (Important: cookie object must be declared)

methods.name: Date.prototype.add

methods.body:
A date/time formatting. If the `format string` starts with `!` the hours will be converted to AM/PM time. Name of days and months can be translated via resources.

```html
d - day e.g. 1
dd - day e.g. 01
ddd - day (named). MO
dddd - day (named). Monday
M - month e.g. 1
MM - month e.g. 01
MMM - month (named). Jan
MMMM - month (named). January
yy - year e.g. 16
yyyy - year e.g. 2016
w - week number e.g. 1
ww - week number e.g. 01
H - hour e.g. 1
HH - hour e.g. 01
m - minute e.g. 1
mm - minute e.g. 01
s - second e.g. 1
ss - second e.g. 01
a - AM/PM
```

```javascript
console.log(new Date().format('dd.MM.yyyy HH:mm:ss'));
console.log(new Date().format()); // returns ISO date without 'Z'

console.log(new Date().format('dd. MMMM yyyy'));
// Output: 12. February 2016

console.log(new Date().format('!HH:mm a'));
// Output: 11:07 AM

// How to translate months and days according to the specific a resource file?
console.log(new Date().format('dddd MMMM yyyy', 'resource_name'));
```

__/resources/resouce_name.resource__:
```html
// Months
January       : JanuÃ¡r
February      : FebruÃ¡r
March         : Marec
...
// Days
Monday        : Pondelok
Thuesday      : Utorok
...```

methods.body:
Usage:

```javascript
// var a = yield sync2(ASYNC_FUNCTION);
```

__IMPORTANT:__ the last argument in `ASYNC_FUNCTION` __has to be__ a CALLBACK delegate like this: `callback(err, value)`.

---

Difference between `sync()` and `sync2()`:

```javascript
var users = yield sync(DATABASE('users').$$all(n => n.age > 10))(); // sync returns function with expression
var users = yield sync2(DATABASE('users').$$all(n => n.age > 10)); // sync2 evals expression```
methods.name: sync2

pages.body:
> Welcome to the **Total.js documentation**. Total.js is free web application framework for building Web sites and Web applications using JavaScript, HTML and CSS. The framework has very simple logic, a short learning curve and many features for creating scalable web applications. Please support Total.js on social networks and [GitHub repository](https://github.com/totaljs/framework).

---

[![Support](https://www.totaljs.com/img/button-support.png)](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)

## How should I read this documentation?

![Undertanding](resources/documentation.png)

## Minimum requirements for Total.js

- CPU: 1x Single Core
- Memory (RAM): 50 MB
- Free hard drive space: 15 MB

---

## Installation options

I recommend to download the framework with __empty project__:

- Install [Node.js platform](http://www.nodejs.org) (recommended: `Node.js +v8.0.0`)
- [Download empty project](https://github.com/totaljs/emptyproject)
- Unpack and run it via terminal:

```bash
$ cd myapp
$ node debug.js
```

__Empty project__ contains entire Total.js framework and 3x startup files `debug.js` (for development), `release.js` (for production) and `test.js` (for assertion testing). __IMPORTANT__: The startup file `debug.js` automatically watches all changes in your project directory and when a change occurs the script restarts the application automatically.

```bash
$ node debug.js
$ node release.js
$ node test.js
```

You can create your own start script if you don't use prepared start scripts:

__With web server__:
```javascript
// require('total.js').http(mode, [options]);
// require('total.js').https(mode, [options]);
// modes: debug, release, test

// The code below starts the framework
require('total.js').http('debug');
```

- [Documentation: F.http()](http://docs.totaljs.com/latest/en.html#api~Framework~F.http)
- `+v2.6.0` contains built-in watcher [Documentation: Watcher](http://docs.totaljs.com/latest/en.html#pages~Watcher)

__Without web server (e.g. for workers)__:
```javascript
// require('total.js').load(mode, types, [path]);
// modes: debug, release, test
// types: models, modules, definitions, controllers, isomorphic, packages, sitemap, dependencies

// The code below starts the framework without web server
require('total.js').load('debug', ['definitions', 'models']);
```

[Documentation: F.load()](http://docs.totaljs.com/latest/en.html#api~Framework~F.load)

> __REMEMBER__: all project files has to have lower case extensions (very important). Our recommendation is to use lower case for files and directories as well.

## Other ways for installation

### 1. NPM (Node Package Manager)

Node.js platform includes [Node Package Manager](http://www.npmjs.com) (NPM). This option installs __total.js__ into current directory.

```bash
$ mkdir myapp
$ cd myapp
$Â npm install total.js --save
```

### 2. NPM (Node Package Manager) installation as a global module

The global module contains executable (binary) app, this app contains many helpful features.

```bash
$Â sudo npm install -g total.js
```

__Try to write__ into the terminal or command-line after installation:

```bash
$Â totaljs -help
```

### Recommendation for directory structure

- Read in Node.js docs - [Loading from node_modules Folders](https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v6.x/docs/api/modules.html#modules_loading_from_node_modules_folders)
- Read in Node.js docs - [Loading from the global folders](https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v6.x/docs/api/modules.html#modules_loading_from_the_global_folders)

__Peter Sirka's configuration__:

```html
/my-app-folder/
/my-app-folder/node_modules/ <!-- create it manually and this directory will contain all Node.js modules -->

/my-app-folder/apps/ <!-- directory will contain your Total.js apps, e.g: -->
/my-app-folder/apps/totaljs_com-www/
/my-app-folder/apps/componentator_com-www/
/my-app-folder/apps/...
```

How can I install Total.js?

```bash
cd /my-app-folder/
npm install total.js
```

__Safe configuration__:

```html
/apps/ <!-- directory will contain your Total.js apps, e.g: -->

/apps/totaljs_com-www/
/apps/totaljs_com-www/node_modules <!-- create it manually and this directory will contain all Node.js modules for this app -->

/apps/componentator_com-www/
/apps/componentator_com-www/node_modules <!-- create it manually and this directory will contain all Node.js modules for this app -->
/apps/...
```

How can I install Total.js?

```bash
cd /apps/totaljs_com-www/
npm install total.js
```

### Read more:

- [Total.js - Tutorial](#pages~Tutorial)
- [Total.js - Directory structure](#pages~Directory%20structure)

pages.name: Tutorial

pages.body:
> __Total.js__ project has a _simple directory structure_. __All directories are optional__ and you can rewrite each path of directory in the framework configuration file.

## Directories

```html
/.src
/components
/configs
/controllers
/databases
/definitions
/isomorphic
/logs
/models
/modules
/operations/
/packages
/private
/public
/resources
/schemas
/source
/startup
/tests
/tmp
/views
/workers
```

### Directory: .src

`+v3.0.0` - This directory is internal directory and it contains extracted files from bundles.

- [How do bundles work?](#pages~Bundles)

---

### Directory: components

`+v2.4.0` - Directory contains only components. Components can contain server-side and client-side implementation together. Components can extend Total.js application easily about great new functionality.

- [How do components work?](#pages~Components)

---

### Directory: configs

`+v1.9.x` - Directory contains only specific config files. Files are loaded in the order and before are read base config files. The framework recognizes files with `-debug`, `-release` and `-test` or without (for all modes) name. Config files have same structure as base config files.

```html
/configs/my-custom-config         - this config file is loaded for all modes (debug, release, test)
/configs/my-custom-config-debug   - this config file is loaded only for debug mode
/configs/my-custom-config-release - this config file is loaded only for release mode
/configs/my-custom-config-test    - this config file is loaded only for test mode
```

---

### Directory: controllers

Directory contains only controllers. In controller you can define routes with different actions. Controllers are __most important__ feature in the framework.

- [How do controllers work?](#pages~Controllers)

---

### Directory: databases

Directory contains __NoSQL embedded databases__ (if are). NoSQL database is a plain text file with serialized documents in JSON format. Some [3rd modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules) store a small data in this directory.

- [How does NoSQL database work?](#api~Database)
- [Example: Database](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/contact-form)

---

### Directory: definitions

Directory contains all definitions. The definition defines behaviour of the framework. The definition is great for changing a behaviour of e.g. modules.

- [How do definitions work?](#pages~Definitions)

---

### Directory: isomorphic

`+v1.9.x` - Directory contains an isomorphic code. The isomorphic means: one code for server-side and client-side.

- [How does isomorphic work?](#pages~Isomorphic)

---

### Directory: logs

Directory contains logs. Log file is plain text file. You can append a log message via `framework.log(message)` everywhere. Log filename is created by date.

- [Example: Logs](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/logs)

---

### Directory: models

Directory contains models. The model can contain functions or some [schemas](#api~SchemaBuilder). Recommended for database models.

- [How do models work?](#pages~Models)
- [Example: Models](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/models)

---

### Directory: modules

Directory contains extended modules. The module can create routes or can contain classes, functions or constants. You can download existing modules or you can create your own module.

- [How do modules work?](#pages~Modules)
- [Example: Modules](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-modules)
- [Download 3rd modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules)

---

### Directory: private

`+v1.9.x` - This directory is private directory for storing custom data.

---

### Directory: public

This directory is published directory and contains all static files (JavaScripts, CSS files, Pictures, Fonts, Documents, Videos, Uploads, etc.). Browser can get (almost) everything from the public directory.

---

### Directory: resources

If you create web pages that will be read by speakers of different languages, you have to provide a way for readers to view the page in their own language. Resources are solution. The resource file has same syntax as a config file.

- [How do resources work?](#pages~Resources)
- [Example: Resources](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/localization-resources)

---

### Directory: startup

__NEW__ `+v2.x.x` - A startup directory can contain scripts which are executed only once. All executed scripts are renamed automatically and on the second start they are not executed. Scripts are executed as worker outside application scope.

---

### Directory: schemas

`+v3.0.0` This directory can contain Total.js schemas only. It's a simple alternative to models.

---

### Directory: source

This directory contains a business logic of your application. The source file can contain functions or objects which can be exported and used in each part of application.

- [Example: Source](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-business-logic-source)

---

### Directory: operations

`+v3.0.0` This directory can contain Total.js operations only.

---

### Directory: packages

This directory contains packages. The package is a file which contains more files packed in one package file. The package behaves like a module (is same as module).

- [How do packages work?](#pages~Packages)

---

### Directory: tests

Test directory contains scripts for assertion testing. In assertion test you can test e.g. controller routing.

- [Example: Tests](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/assertion-testing)

---

### Directory: tmp

This directory is a temporary directory and contains temporary files. The framework stores some compiled files, internal cache and form uploads into this directory.

---

### Directory: views

This directory contains views and layouts.

---

### Directory: workers

This directory contains workers. The worker creates a new independent thread, which can communicate with framework through events.

- [Example: Workers](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/workers)
- [Example: Generating sitemap with the Worker](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/xml-sitemap-workers)

- [__Visual Studio Code syntax highlighter for Total.js__](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=pnmcosta.vscode-totaljs)

---

## A minimal framework configuration for running

The framework is really simple, you can create the website very easily:

Create `myapp.js`:

```javascript
require('total.js').http('debug');

ROUTE('/', function() {
	this.plain('Total.js is really good Node.js framework!');
});
```

__Run it__:

```bash
$ node myapp.js
```

You have a full web server with all Total.js features in the above code.

---

## Total.js binary / executable app

Install Total.js as a global module `$ npm install -g total.js` and then you can use a lot of great features:

- `$ totaljs --help`
- local webserver with directory listing `$ cd somedir` and `$ totaljs 8000` (starts webserver)
- translation tools `$ totaljs --translate`
- minifications tools `$ totaljs --minify script.js` (works with CSS and HTML too)
- create empty project `$ mkdir app`, `$ cd app` and `$ totaljs`

---

Controllers

pages.body:
Definitions can rewrite existing functionality or add a new. The definition can define the framework behavior and it does not have any other logic. __In short__: the definition is a coded configuration file.

```plain
Framework initialization:

01. Bundles
02. Modules
03. Packages
04. Models
05. Schemas
06. Operations
07. Themes
08. Definitions
09. Controllers
10. Components
```

__More informations__

- The definition is the plain JavaScript file with `.js` extension.
- All definitions are stored in `your-app/definitions/` directory.
- Each definitions is executed automatically and one time.
- You can create unlimited number of definitions
- The definition can be injected from the URL address, [example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-install-definition).

---

## Examples

Following [examples](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/) contain definitions.

- [Example: Install the definition from URL](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-install-definition)
- [Example: The definition with MongoDB driver](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/mongodb)

---

## The definition

The definition file contains only the code to run, nothing more.

### A full example of definition

E.g. create: `definitions/database.js`

```javascript
var DB = null;

require('mongodb').MongoClient.connect('connection-string-to-database', function(err, db) {
	if (err)
		throw err;
	DB = db;
});

// Rewrite built-in functionality
F.database = function(collection) {
	return collection ? DB.collection(collection) : DB;
};
```
pages.name: Definitions
Modules

pages.body:
> __The Package__ is same as Total.js module, but the Package can contain multiple files packed in the single `package` file. ```plain Framework initialization: 01. Bundles 02. Modules 03. Packages 04. Models 05. Schemas 06. Operations 07. Themes 08. Definitions 09. Controllers 10. Components ``` __More informations__ - the package is a plain text file with `.package` extension - the framework unpacks the package into the temporary directory - all packages are stored in `your-app/packages/` directory - `index.js` is the main file of the package and has to __the same structure as the module__ - `exports.install` is executed automatically and once - views can be mapped from the package easily: `controller.view('@packagename/myview')` - views and static files have to be mapped manually via `F.map()` - you can create unlimited number of packages - the package can be injected from a URL address - [Download packages](https://github.com/totaljs/modules) - `+v2.8.0` a package file can be large (mechanism supports streaming) `PACKAGE == MODULE with dependencies` --- ## How to create a package? You can create Total.js package easily. First you need to install Total.js framework from NPM as a __global__ modul. Then open terminal and write `$ tpm --help`, `tpm` is Total.js CLI tool installed from NPM. ### Creating own packages (debug-mode) - create a directory `packages` in your application - then create sub-directory `/packages/helloworld/` - then create these files: __1. Create__ `/packages/helloworld/index.js`: ```javascript // THIS IS A START SCRIPT FOR THE PACKACAGE exports.install = function(options) { console.log('Hello from the package!'); // Routing ROUTE('/hello-world/', view_greeting); // Mapping for static files MAP('/myview.js', '@helloworld/myview.js'); }; function view_greeting() { // IMPORTANT: for the view will be used a layout out of this package. // or create your own this.layout('@helloworld/layout') this.view('@helloworld/myview'); } ``` __2. Create__ `/packages/helloworld/myview.html`: ```html
Hello from the package
``` __3. Create__ `/packages/helloworld/myview.js`: ```javascript alert('Hello world!'); ``` __3. Run app:__ ```bash $ node debug.js ``` Open: `http://0.0.0.0:8000/hello-world/` in your browser. ### Creating a package - open terminal in the app and open directory with your package `$ cd /packages/helloworld/` - this command `$ tpm create helloworld` will create a package `helloworld.package` - now you can use your new package --- ## Booting Booting is a special feature in Total.js framework. The file `index.js` in a package can contain: ### Booting all files The framework unpacks package and evaluates all files according to the framewok's directory structure. So the framework will load controllers, modules, definitions, configs, etc. from the package. ```javascript exports.booting = true; ``` ### Booting as application The framework unpacks package and it will run it as an application. Example: `F.http('debug', { package: 'myapp.package' })` and settings in a package: ```javascript exports.booting = 'root'; ``` ### Custom options via configuration files `+v2.4.0` supports a new feature: the custom options for modules which can be defined in configuration files. Each package is a module in the end. ```html // type#name (Object) : { name: 'value', number: 20, boolean: true } package#flow (Object) : { url: '/flow/' }; package#dashboard (Object) : { url: '/dashboard/' }; module#monitor (Object) : { url: '/mymonitor/' } module#webcounter (Object) : { xhr: true, ip: true }```
pages.name: Packages
Models

pages.body: The resource file is a simple KEY/VALUE dictionary. Resources are simple and very effective and the framework uses resources for [localization](#pages~Localization). - The resource is the plain text file with `.resource` extension. - Framework loads each resource into the memory when is needed. - You can create unlimited number of resources. - Resources are readonly. - Resources are used for validation. [Example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation) - [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools) - `+v2.8.0` supports sub-types ##Â Examples - [Example: Localization](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/localization-resources) - [Example: Validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation) - [Example: Custom validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation-custom) --- ## The definition ###Â resources/default.resource ```html key1 : value1 // comment key2 : value2 key3 : with the tag // v2.8.0 supports sub-types: key5 (Array) : [1, 2, 3, 4] key6 (Object) : { name: 'Peter', age: 33 } key7 (config) : secret ``` ### resources/en.resource ```html key1 : value1-en // comment key2 : value2-en key3 : with the tag-en ``` ### resources/de.resource ```html key1 : value1-de // comment key2 : value2-de key3 : with the tag-de ``` ## Reading values from resources - [Documentation: RESOURCE()](#api~global~RESOURCE) - [Documentation: framework.resource()](#api~Framework~framework.resource) - [Documentation: controller.resource()](#api~FrameworkController~controller.resource) ```javascript console.log(RESOURCE('key1')); console.log(framework.resource('key1')); // value1 console.log(RESOURCE('en', 'key1')); // value1-en console.log(RESOURCE('de', 'key1')); // value1-de ``` ### View engine ```html @{resource('key3')} @{!resource('key3')} @{resource('en', 'key3')} @{!resource('en', 'key3')} @{resource('de', 'key3')} @{!resource('de', 'key3')} ```
pages.name: Resources

pages.body:
`Views` can render HTML. You can render "view" in "view" and "view" is rendered into the layout at the end. The view engine supports conditions, loops, sections, helpers and inline helpers. --- __More informations__ - View is the plain HTML file with `.html` extension. - __IMPORTANT:__ Server tags are represented as `@{keyword}` (encoded) tag and `@{!keyword}` (raw) tag. - Views are synchronous. - Views are compiled into the function. - All views (HTML) are minimized under the compilation (Total.js saves memory). - The layout is rendered at the last (if it's not disabled). - You can render some view into the string. - The default layout filename is `layout.html`, in older versions has been `_layout.html`. - When the path starts with `~` char then the framework maps the path into the views root directory - When the path starts with `.` char then the framework skips `.` and it loads the view without support of the framework configuration (the view can be outside of app directory) - [View properties and methods](#api~FrameworkViews) - [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools) --- ### Examples Following [examples](https://github.com/totaljs/examples) contain views. - [Example: Views](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views) - [Example: Views with XHR](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-xhr) - [Example: Views places and sections](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-place-sections) - [Example: Views meta](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-meta) - [Example: Views inline JavaScript compress](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-javascript-compress) - [Example: Views head](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-head) - [Example: Views custom helper](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-custom-helper) --- ## Repository vs. Model There are many ways how to send some values between controllers and views. You can transfer data between the controller and the view via `controller.repository` or `controller.view('name', model)`. ```javascript exports.install = function() { F.route('/', view_homepage); }; function view_homepage() { var self = this; self.repository.firstname = 'Peter'; self.view('my-view', { firstname: 'Lucia' }); } ``` A picture describes the behaviour of variables: ![Repository vs. model](resources/viewengine-repository-vs-model.png) ```html

My View

Get the value from the repository: @{repository.firstname}
Get the value from the model: @{model.firstname}
@{view('partial-view-1', model)}
@{view('partial-view-2')}
``` ## Defining the layout You can create unlimited layouts and customize them according the name. The layout is the same as the view. The only difference is tag `@{body}`. Into this tag is rendered the view. ### The layout example ```html @{meta} @{head} @{import('default.css', 'default.js', 'favicon.ico')}
@{section('panel')} @{body}
@{view('footer')} ``` Read more about [view engine tags](#api~FrameworkViews). --- ## Defining the view You can create unlimited views. ### Example ```html @{meta('Title', 'Description (optional)', 'Keywords (optional)')}
Hello World!
@{view('products', [{ name: 'A', price: 23.32 }, { name: 'B', price: 32.10 }])} @{view('users', model)} @{view('products', [{ name: 'A', price: 23.32 }, { name: 'B', price: 32.10 }, { name: 'C', price: 15.22 }])} ``` ## Escaping The view engine automatically escape HTML entities. Tag with `@{!` renders the raw value. ```html @{repository.tag = 'Hello World'}
ESCAPED: @{repository.tag}
RAW: @{!repository.tag}
``` __Output__: ```html
ESCAPED: Hello <b>World</b>
RAW: Hello World
``` ## Conditions - supports `else if` in `+v1.9.1` ```html @{if user === null}
sign in
@{else}
sign up
@{fi}

@{if model.name === 'Peter'} @{if model.name === 'Lucia'}
Here is Lucia.
@{else}
Here is Peter.
@{fi} @{fi}

@{if model.name !== 'Peter'}
Here is @{model.name}
@{fi} ``` ## Looping __Array looping__: ```html @{foreach m in [1, 2, 3, 4]}
@{m}, index: @{index}
@{end}

@{foreach property in model}
@{index}
@{property.name}
@{property.age.format('### ###')}
@{end} ``` __Object looping__: ```html @{foreach m in { name: 'Peter', age: 32 }}
property: @{m.key}, value: @{m.value}
@{end}

@{foreach property in model}
@{index}
@{property.key}
@{property.value}
@{end} ``` ## Sections __View__: ```html @{section footer}
THIS IS FOOTER FROM THE VIEW
@{end}

Homepage


``` __Layout__: ```html .... .... @{body} .... .... @{section('footer')} .... .... ``` __Output__: ```html .... ....

Homepage


.... ....
THIS IS FOOTER FROM THE VIEW
.... .... ``` ## Assignment values __SUPPORTS ONLY:__ repository, model, user, session, global, get, post and config. ```html @{repository.name = 'Peter'}

@{repository.name}

``` __Output__: ```html

Peter

``` ## Defining helpers ```javascript F.helpers.custom = function(str, num) { // this === controller return str + ' = ' + num; }; framework.helpers.isTrue = function(value) { return value ? true : false; }; ``` ```html @{custom('Peter', 25)} @{helpers.custom('Peter', 25)} @{if helpers.isTrue(true)} Helpers in condition. The helper isTrue won't work without helpers keyword. @{fi} ``` ## Defining inline helpers The inline helper has to by defined in the view. ```html @{helper address(street, city)

Address

@{street}
@{city}

@{end}
Address 1
@{address('Baker street 3', 'Wien')}
Address 2
@{address('Galvaniho 3', 'Bratislava')} ``` ## Defining custom 3rd compilers The view engine supports custom 3rd compilers. [How to write a connection to 3rd compiler?](#api~Framework~framework.onCompileView) ```html

HANDLEBARS

@{compile handlebars}

Handlebars: {{ title }}

{{ body }}

@{end}

JADE

@{compile jade} h3 View engine p Total.js is amazing! @{end} ``` ## Date feature `date` function compares the current date with date in the argument. ```html @{if date('>', '2015-01-01') && date('<', '2015-01-10 12:00')}
! Happy new year !
@{fi} @{viewToggle(date('=', '2014-08-08'), 'important-partial-view')} ``` ## Defining views in sub-directories The default controller `default.js` includes views from the default views directory `/views`. To modify this behaviour, rename the controller's filename (e.g: `controllers/site.js`) to match a directory of the same name under views (e.g: `views/site/`). The views contained within the `site` directory would be displayed. __IMPORTANT__: char `~` is very important for mapping path of views, because `~index` is still routed into the `/views/index.html`. --- ## Localization The framework automatically translates `@(text)` when compiling the views. - [How does localization work?](#pages~Localization) ```html @{meta('@(My custom title)', '@(Description to translate)')}

@(Hello world)

@(Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur ...)

@(#T-3403403030)

@(#T34930203922)

``` ## Auto binding values ```javascript function view_contactform() { this.view('contactform', { Email: '@', Name: 'Anoym' }); }; ``` ## Reading a value from the configuration - +v2.8.0 supports binding values directly from the `F.config` ```html
F.config.name: @{'%name'}
F.config['manager-url']: @{'%manager-url'}
``` ## Simple routing to static files ```html @{import('ui.js')} @{import('ui.css')} ``` __View__: ```html Email: @{text('Email')} Name: @{text('Name')} ``` __Output__: ```html Email: Name: ```

pages.body:
The localization is big tool for multilingual websites. - The framework translates views at time of compilation. - Each translated view is stored into the memory. - For generating translations is needed `total` (An executable file). - The text for translate is wrapped with `@()` tag (it will be a default text). - [Documentation: F.translate()](#api~Framework~framework.translate) - For setting the language for the current request use [F.onLocale()](#api~Framework~framework.onLocale) delegate __IMPORTANT__: - Localized text doesn't start with `#sometext` because for the framework is `sometext` key and the framework reads this key directly from the resource file. - __IMPORTANT__ if your localized text contains `"` or `'` chars then perform HTML encode e.g. `"` to `"` and `'` to `'` because some localized text can be used in inline JavaScript strings. --- ## Full example ### First step You has to install `total.js` as global module from NPM: ```bash $ sudo npm install -g total.js ``` ### Implementation The definition: ```javascript F.onLocale = function(req) { if (req.query.language === 'sk') return 'sk'; return 'en'; }; ``` The controller: ```javascript exports.install = function() { ROUTE('/', view_index); }; function view_index() { var self = this; // you can change language manually here, e.g.: // self.language = 'sk'; self.view('index'); } ``` The view: ```html @{meta('@(Title)')}

@(Hello world!)

@(Total.js is web application framework for Node.js)

@(#message) or @(#T80818744) is same as @(Title) (read below)
``` ### Create resource __1.__ Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ totaljs --translate ``` The Total Application finds all texts for translation and creates the resource file `translate.resource` for translation. The keys are numbers in the resource file because the framework saves the performance and memory (saves RAM). Rename below file to `en.resource`: ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Title T-52966915 : Hello world! T-1870230665 : Total.js is web application framework for Node.js // IMPORTANT: This line was created manually message : Direct reading ``` __2.__ Copy the content from `translate.resource` to the new resource: `/resources/sk.resource` and I translate it, e.g.: ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Titulok T-52966915 : Ahoj svet! T-1870230665 : Total.js je webový framework pre Node.js // IMPORTANT: This line was created manually message : Priame čítanie ``` ### Run `http://0.0.0.0:8000` ```html ... ... Title ... ...

Hello world!

Total.js is web application framework for Node.js

Direct reading or Title is same as Title (read below)
... ... ``` `http://0.0.0.0:8000/?language=sk` ```html ... ... Titulok ... ...

Ahoj svet!

Total.js je webový framework pre Node.js

Priame čítanie or Titulok is same as Titulok (read below)
... ... ``` ## Did you know? ### Resource file can contain view engine tags Resource with the localization can contain view engine markup and the markup will be evaluated. ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Hello @{user.name}! ``` ## Translation tools If you installed __Total.js__ from NPM as global module then you have available translation tools. ### Tracking of new changes The command `-diff` creates the resource file with changes between two resources (newest texts and removed texts). Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ totaljs -diff en.resource de.resource ``` ### Translating text files Content of __my-translation.txt__: ```html Hello World! I help you My name is Peter. Total.js is the web application framework ``` Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ totaljs --translate my-translation.txt ``` ### Translating custom phrases Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ totaljs --translate "Hello World" ``` Output: ``` T-862545276 : Hello World ``` ### Translating views into the CSV - `+v1.9.0` ```bash $ totaljs --translatecsv```

pages.body:
- By default the view engine encodes all values.
- The framework works only with object (POST/GET/DELETE/PUT data are parsed as object).
- Use AJAX/XHR form submitting for the [CSRF attacks](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_request_forgery) protection.
- The framework supports method for setting [CORS](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-origin_resource_sharing).
- The framework supports auto-binding model into the forms.
- The framework automatically checks incoming requests and the bad requests destroys automatically.
- The framework checks length of uploading files.
- All requests are destroyed when don't have a defined route.

---

- [Example: CORS](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/cors)

pages.body:
__Table of contents:__

1. [Minify 3rd static files like CSS or JavaScript](#)
2. [Less is more in View Engine](#)
3. [Know the framework](#)
4. [Use schemas](#)

---

## Minify 3rd static files like CSS or JavaScript

Always __use CDN__. Otherwise minify unnecessary scripts or styles (e.g. from 3rd party companies) and rename to `somename.min.js` or `somename.min.css`. Framework doesn't compile minified files again and you can save the memory and CPU.

---

## Less is more in View Engine

Less of server-side code `@{}` in view engine is better for the performance. Server-side code use when you really need.

---

## Know the framework

Look into the documentation and use all framework features which you need. You don't need more except of database module or specific modules for the project.

---

## Use schemas

Schemas are great for the clean up project. With schemas you can do everything. So insert all business logic into the schemas and write unit-tests. A complete models you can share between projects.
pages.name: Best practices

pages.body:
__Themes__ (`+v1.9.4`) are very helpful for multiple designs. - independent on controllers - themes are composed from views and static files - themes can contain own static files (the framework maps them automatically) - themes support an initialization script `themes/THEME_NAME/index.js` - [__THEMES EXAMPLE__](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/themes) --- ## Initialization file ```plain Framework initialization: 01. Bundles 02. Modules 03. Packages 04. Models 05. Schemas 06. Operations 07. Themes 08. Definitions 09. Controllers 10. Components ``` - is optional - filename `themes/THEME_NAME/index.js` ```javascript exports.install = function() { // ... // ... // space for your code // ... // ... }; ``` ## A default theme for all controllers __Configuration file__ (e.g. `config`, `config-debug`, `config-release` or `config-test`): ```html default-theme : THEME_NAME ``` or ```javascript F.config['default-theme'] = 'THEME_NAME'; ``` ## Change the theme in the controller ```javascript function some_action_in_controller() { var self = this; self.theme('THEME_NAME'); self.view('index'); } ``` __IMPORTANT__: - all views will be routed into the `/theme/THEME_NAME/views/` directory (with `layout`) - themes doesn't support fallback for views - behaviour is same as in views outside of themes --- ## Views ```html
CURRENT THEME: @{theme}
--- @{import('~common.css', 'default.css')} --- is same as: or @{image('logo.png')} ``` ## Public directory in themes __Directory structure__: ```html /themes/THEME_NAME/public/img/logo.png /themes/THEME_NAME/public/js/default.js /themes/THEME_NAME/public/css/default.css ``` __Listening on__: ```html http://0.0.0.0:8000/THEME_NAME/img/logo.png http://0.0.0.0:8000/THEME_NAME/js/default.js http://0.0.0.0:8000/THEME_NAME/css/default.css ``` ## Merging & Mapping - the framework identifies `=THEME_NAME` as a full theme path ```javascript // Merging MERGE('/merged-script.js', 'default.js', '=THEME_NAME/public/js/default.js'); MERGE('/merged-style.css', 'default.css', '=THEME_NAME/public/css/default.css'); // Mapping MAP('/mapped-script.js', '=THEME_NAME/public/js/default.js'); MAP('/mapped-style.css', '=THEME_NAME/public/css/default.css'); ``` ## Special cases - `~view_name` will be routed into the root of current theme `/theme/THEME_NAME/views/` - `~~view_name` will be routed into the root of `views` directory `/views/` ## Routing with themes - `F.view()` - `F.route(url, viewname)` - `F.mail()` - `controller.mail()` ```html =THEME_NAME/name : is routed into the file: /themes/THEME_NAME/views/name.html =?/name : is routed into the default theme's directory /themes/???_FRAMEWORK_DETERMINES_???/views/name.html ``` Same way are with static files but the framework recognizes extensions and by them creates routing.
pages.name: Themes
Isomorphic code

pages.body:
Bundles are big feature in Total.js framework `+v3.0.0`. You can create unlimited count of bundles and a bundle can be a part or core of the application. Imagine that you have a CMS with many files and you don't want to see these files in your e.g. new project because they are useless for you but they are important for the project. So you can create a bundle which will contain these files and your project structure will be really clean. You will love bundles.

Bundle is something similiar like `.zip` file, but it's not real `zip`. Bundle file has same structure like Total.js package but it has another extension called `.bundle`.

---

## How does it work?

__Content of bundle `cms.bundle`__:

```html
/controllers/default.js
/definitions/helpers.js
/config
```

__Project structure__:

```html
/bundles/cms.bundle
/definition/db.js
/config
/debug.js
```

__If you run the app__ then the project structure will be updated by adding `.src` directory like this:

```html
/.src/
/.src/controllers/default.js
/.src/definitions/helpers.js
/.src/definitions/db.js
/.src/config
/definition/db.js
/config
/debug.js
```

The framework extracts all bundles + copies all files from project structure into `.src` directory. Then the framework runs app from `.src` directory.

__Good to know__:

- Total.js framework extracts bundles first
- then the framework (IMPORTANT) merges `resources` and `config` files
- then the framework copies/rewrites all files from project directory
- then the framework runs the app from `.src` directory (this directory will be as root)
- the framework creates a file of file structure called `/.src/bundle.json` (so if you remove/create some file then the framework updates `.src` structure automatically)
- `.src/databases` directory is synchronized only for new files, in other words: framework doesn't modify this directory

---

## How to create a bundle?

It's very easy, first you need to install Total.js as a global module `$ npm install -g total.js` and then you can use CLI tool called `$ tpm` (Total Package Manager)

```bash
$ cd yourapp
$ tpm bundle myapp
```

## FAQ

### Can a bundle contain packages?
Yes, it can contain packages.

---

### Can a bundle contain sub-bundles?
No, it's not possible.

---

### Are files with same names between bundles and project structure rewritten?
Yes, they are rewritten according to the project structure because these files have a bigger priority than files in bundles. __IMPORTANT__: `config` files, `resources`, `sitemap` file, `workflows` file, `versions` file and `dependencies` files are merged.
pages.name: Bundles

pages.body:
A sitemap file `/sitemap` (`+v1.9.1`) is very helpful generating breadcrumb (navigation) or sitemap. The sitemap file `/sitemap` is a plain text and has same syntax as framework config file. - [Example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/sitemap) ```html /controllers /debug.js /release.js /sitemap ``` ## Declaration ```html ID : Name --> URL --> [Parent (OPTIONAL)] ``` ## How does it work? File: `/sitemap` e.g.: ```html homepage : Homepage --> / contact : Contact --> /contact/ --> homepage terms : Terms and Conditions --> /terms/ --> homepage privacy : @(Localized Privacy) --> @(/privacy/) --> terms ``` - sitemap `name` can be as view title (when is the title not defined in the view) - supports localization `@(Text to translate)` - `v2.0.2` URL addreses can be localized too ### Usage in views __View layout.html__: ```html
@{foreach m in sitemap()} @{m.name} @{end}
``` __View index.html__: ```html @{sitemap('homepage')}

@{title}

``` __View terms.html__: ```html @{sitemap('terms')}

@{title}

``` __View privacy.html__: ```html @{sitemap('privacy')}

@{title}

``` __View contact.html__: ```html @{sitemap('contact')}

@{title}

``` ### Usage in the code - [F.sitemap](#api~Framework~F.sitemap) `+v1.9.1` ```javascript // Finds only the one item and it returns Object console.log(F.sitemap('terms', true)); // Finds all items in the sitemap tree and it returns Array console.log(F.sitemap('terms')); ``` ## Routing ```javascript // Creates route according to the sitemap ROUTE('#sitemap_id', [action], [flags]); // Or without additional arguments. As a view name will be used sitemap_id // IMPORTANT: the sitemap mechanism sets title automatically according to the sitemap ROUTE('#sitemap_id'); // Or with a view name: // IMPORTANT: the sitemap mechanism sets title automatically according to the sitemap ROUTE('#sitemap_id', 'index'); // +v2.9.0 supports additional sitemap routing ROUTE('#sitemap_id/products/', [action], [flags]); ROUTE('#sitemap_id/orders/', [action], [flags]);```
pages.name: File: sitemap

pages.body:
A dependency file `/dependencies` (`+v1.9.0`) is very helpful for installing different dependencies from URL address like models, modules, controllers, configuration files, packages, etc.. The dependency file `/dependencies` is a plain text and has same syntax as __framework config file__.

```html
/controllers
/debug.js
/release.js
/dependencies
```

## How does it work?

File: `/dependencies` with:

```html
module              : https://cdn.totaljs.com/monitor.js
package             : https://cdn.totaljs.com/console.package
package             : https://cdn.totaljs.com/webcounter.js --> { "ip": true }
```

## How to define a custom settings for dependency?

Example:

```html
package            : http://url-address.com --> { "custom-settings": "serialized in JSON format" }
```


## Up-To-Date feature

`+v2.4.0` supports up-to-date feature and now your dependencies can be up-to-date.

```html
// type (INTERVAL)  : URL ADDRESS --> OPTIONAL OPTIONS
package  (1 day)    : http://url-address.com --> { "custom-settings": "serialized in JSON format" }
```
pages.name: File: dependencies

pages.body: ## Versioning static files The framework (`+v1.9.0`) has great mechanism for versioning of static files. The versioning is supported via `/versions` file in app root directory. The versioning is very great solution for solving HTTP cache. The versioning file `/versions` is a plain text file and has same syntax as __framework config file__ with except `-->` remapping. So if you have a problem with HTTP cache, this feature saves your time. __Where do I have to store this file?__ ```html /controllers /debug.js /release.js /versions ``` ## How does it work? File: `/versions` with: ```html /js/default.js : /js/default-101.js /css/default.css : /css/default-105.css /img/logo.png : /img/logo-101.png ``` `v3.0.0` adds a support for auto-generating filename: ```html /js/default.js : auto /css/default.css : auto ``` Framework downloads the file immediately and performs MD5 checksum + CRC32 and adds the result into the filename. Auto-generating names can't be used with mapping `-->`. ### 1. affects all views: ```html @{js('default.js')} --> output will be /js/default-101.js @{img('logo.png')} --> output will be /img/logo-101.png @{css('default.css')} --> output will be /css/default-105.css Output file has to exist or has to be served via `MERGE()` or `MAP()` --> output will be --> output will be --> output will be ``` ### 2. affects `MERGE()` and `MAP()`: ```javascript MERGE('/js/default.js', 'scriptA.js', 'scriptB.js'); // The framework automatically remaps MERGE() on the background to: // MERGE('/js/default-101.js', 'scriptA.js', 'scriptB.js'); MAP('/js/default.js', 'newfile.js'); // The framework automatically remaps MAP() on the background to: // MAP('/js/default-101.js', 'newfile.js'); ``` --- File: `/versions` with remapping: > Below solution solves problem with renaming of files. You don't need to rename file `/img/logo.png` to `img/logo-101.png`. The framework automatically creates a file mapping. So in the prax: you change old __logo file__ without renaming. ```html /img/logo.png --> /img/logo-101.png ``` The framework automatically creates `MAP()` e.g. `MAP('/img/logo-101.png','/img/logo.png')` and it has same behaviour like versioning without remapping. --- - [Example: versioning of static files](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/static-version)
